name: Zilong Wang
title: Research Scientist at Google DeepMind
about: Zilong Wang is a final-year Ph.D. student at UC San Diego, advised by Prof. Jingbo Shang. He specializes in natural language reasoning and multimodal data mining, with expertise in post-training and distilling language models to enhance reasoning and planning capabilities. His work also focuses on evaluating the reliability and robustness of LLMs in safety-critical contexts and integrating multimodal features to address tasks involving tables, images, and web pages. At Google, Zilong developed Speculative RAG, an RAG framework that achieves state-of-the-art performance both in accuracy and efficiency. This method employs a map-reduce framework, where smaller specialist LMs generate draft responses, which are then verified and refined by a larger generalist LM. Zilong also created the Chain-of-Table agent framework for solving tabular understanding tasks. This system allows LLMs to outline their reasoning step-by-step, iteratively updating a table to reflect the reasoning process. By segmenting tables into manageable parts, Chain-of-Table enhances the depth of table analysis. Additionally, Zilong developed an LLM debugging agent (LDB) to improve coding capabilities. The agent leverages runtime execution data to iteratively refine LLM-generated programs, achieving state-of-the-art performance on coding benchmarks such as HumanEval and MBPP. Earlier in his research, Zilong focused on Document AI, proposing LayoutReader, a multimodal model for detecting reading order in visually-rich documents. He has extended this experience to current LLM systems, introducing OfficeBench, a new agent benchmark for office automation tasks. Zilong has completed research internships at Google, Microsoft, Amazon, and Adobe, and his work has been published in top venues such as ICLR, ACL, EMNLP, and KDD.
